content.webTitle: Senate's CIA torture report: everyone has an opinion except the White House

fields.headline: Senate's CIA torture report: everyone has an opinion except the White House
fields.bodyText: The White House has been left stranded between rapidly polarising reactions to the Senate torture report on Tuesday as officials refused to say whether they agreed with its chief finding that the brutal techniques used by the CIA were of no practical use in fighting terrorism. The administration also ducked the question of whether it would be taking any action against intelligence chiefs alleged to have covered up the extent of prisoner abuse, preferring to focus on the need to restore morale in the agency in the wake of the report and guard against possible reprisals overseas. With President Obama safely in the air on the way to a pre-arranged visit to Kentucky, it was primarily left to anonymous “senior administration officials” to brief the media on his muted response to the damning report. “We are spending an awful lot of time on the morale of the [CIA] workforce right now,” said one of five senior officials on a background conference call. “The protection of our people is our top priority,” added another, who said the State Department had put every US posting in the world on heightened security standby in anticipation of the report’s release. John Kerry, the US secretary of state, echoed the relative lack of contrition among US government figures who stressed their distance from the previous policy but unwillingness to hold individuals to account. “I want to underscore that while it’s uncomfortable and unpleasant to re-examine this period, it’s important that this period not define the intelligence community in anyone’s minds,” he said. “Rather than another reason to refight old arguments, I hope that today’s report can help us leave these techniques where they belong – in the past,” added Obama in a prepared statement released shortly before the Senate intelligence committee chair, Dianne Feinstein, documented the catalogue of abuses and alleged cover-ups. In a speech in Nashville, the president stuck to a pre-arranged script on immigration reform and did not address the torture report at all. But the administration’s relative silence was in stark contrast to the firestorm in the rest of Washington caused by Feinstein’s tougher-than-expected report. The Republican foreign policy hawk John McCain, himself a victim of torture during the Vietnam war, was damning of the agency, claiming the CIA had “stained our national honour” and “damaged our security interests as well as our reputation for being a force for good in the world”. The outgoing Democratic Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, was also firmly behind the intelligence committee in the fight against practices he said had “got us nothing, except a bad name” and were “not in keeping with our country”. But the CIA and Republican allies in Congress were not taking the criticism lying down. John Brennan, the Bush-era veteran in charge of the agency, issued a statement acknowledging some “shortcomings and mistakes” but vigorously rejected allegations of a systematic cover-up. “Our review indicates that interrogations of detainees on whom enhanced interrogation techniques were used did produce intelligence that helped thwart attack plans, capture terrorists, and save lives,” he added. “The intelligence gained from the programme was critical to our understanding of al-Qaida and continues to inform our counterterrorism efforts to this day.” Senator Saxby Chambliss, the senior Republican on the intelligence committee, published his own report flatly contradicting the principal findings of Democrats and two other members, which he called “erroneous and inflammatory”. “There is no telling how many lives this programme saved,” said Chamblis, pointing to 766 cases he claimed where “sole sourced” intelligence had been extracted, including warning of terrorist attacks on Heathrow airport and London’s Canary Wharf. But the White House insisted it was “inappropriate” to comment on the report’s conclusions about the effectiveness of torture or the past candour of CIA officials with the Bush administration. “I think that’s something we’re not passing judgment on,” said the press secretary, Josh Earnest, during an exchange with reporters on Air Force One, insisting former administration officials should “speak for themselves” on whether they felt misled. Obama’s director of national intelligence, James Clapper, who also stood behind the agency after revelations of its domestic surveillance programmes, summed up the ambivalent official response to the torture report. “In all of my experience in intelligence, I am hard-pressed to recall another report – and the issues surrounding it – as fraught with controversy and passion as this one,” he said. “Virtually no one who has any familiarity with the report and what it describes is ‘neutral’.” Except, that is, perhaps the commander in chief and his administration.
